newsitem.title: JAPAN: Oracle CEO knocks Microsoft, touts NC system.
newsitem.headline: Oracle CEO knocks Microsoft, touts NC system.

text.p: Oracle Corp's outspoken chief executive officer Larry Ellison on Wednesday launched a new salvo at Microsoft Corp, stating that information and computers do not belong to "one company and one person".

Ellison, a major promoter of new stripped-down, low-cost network computers (NCs) that can access the Internet, said one of the problems of personal computers was that they depended on Microsoft's Windows software.
"Windows belongs to one company and one person...but information never belongs to one country, one company, one person," Ellison said.
He touted the advantages of NCs, saying they were simple, inexpensive and easy for everyone to build, while PCs were "expensive and complex".
Ellison made the comments during the Oracle Open World exhibition in Tokyo, where Oracle and 30 Japanese partners supporting NCs displayed their NC software.
The 30 manufacturers and systems integrators included NEC Corp and Akai Electric Co.
"Now, our NC project has moved on to reality from vision," said Tsutomu Sano, president of Oracle's Japan unit.
Ellison said in a news conference that he expected sales of 100 million NC units in 2000.
This would represent 90 percent of the global market for personal-use computers.
"Network computers will greatly outsell personal computers (PCs)," he said.
Ellison said Oracle and its partners planned to package five client appliances and one server, together with cables, keyboards and other equipment necessary for a complete network, for $4,999.
The product would be called "Network in a Box", he said.
Ellison said the cost of a network computer terminal would range from $295 to $795. The cost of a server would range from $1,495 to $9,999.
Oracle last year formed a new company to promote network computers.
International Business Machines Corp, Apple Computer Inc, Netscape Communications Corp and Sun Microsystems Inc have expressed support for the idea of network computers.
